trial_identification.studytitle: Treatment of personality disorders using a whole of service guidelines-based approach
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Treatment of personality disorders using a whole of service guidelines-based approach to improve functioning and reduce hospital use: a delayed randomised controlled trial

interventions.interventions: Active intervention is a whole of service guidelines-based treatment based on a relationship model, and will be compared to treatment as usual (TAU). The approach emphasises good clinical care grounded in developed treatment guidelines (Project Air Strategy for Personality Disorders 2011) derived from the NICE (2009) and Gunderson and Links Clinical Guide for treating people with Personality Disorders (2008). Specialised individual, group and family interventions are delivered weekly by mental health professionals for up to 12 months. Service sections are randomly divided into practice sites receiving the intervention or treatment as usual. After a 12-month delay, the TAU sites receive the intervention.
interventions.comparator: Treatment as usual standard care. Standard care involves medical care and case management by health care professionals for up to 12 months and will vary on a case-by-case basis.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in hospital use measured by audit of medical record admission and discharge data.
Change in patient clinical functioning as measured by clinical assessment of diagnostic personality disorder criteria symptoms (number and severity of DSM-IV personality disorder diagnostic criteria)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in likert scale ratings of therapist confidence and skills in treating personality disorders measured by questionnaire.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Meets diagnostic criteria for Personality Disorder Ability and willingness to give informed consent and comply with study procedures Aged 12 or older Seeking treatment at a service within the indicated geographical location Fluent in English
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Psychiatric condition due to a medical condition Primary diagnosis of Schizophrenia or Drug and Alcohol Dependence Are unlikely to be able to read and understand the information sheet and consent form

trial_design.concealment: Participants will be recruited from the NSW Health Illawarra-Shoalhaven and South Eastern Sydney Local Health Districts. All patients who meet the inclusion criteria will be eligible to participate in this study. Written and informed consent will be obtained from all participants. Service sections randomly divided into practice sites recieving intervention or treatment as usual. Participants were unaware (blind) to allocation status. Allocation was done off site by randomisation generator.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Treatment for personality disorder is effective but only specialist long-term approaches have been studied on specific subsets of patients with highly trained staff. This study aims to evaluate a whole of service approach in a large public mental health service. The treatment is guidelines-based approach based on a relationship model (Project Air Strategy for Personality Disorders 2011). A delayed randomised controlled trial compares this approach to standard care.
